answer.para: Questions upon Notice (Question No. 1398)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Labour and National Service, upon notice:

quote.para: When may an answer be expected to Questions Nos 1133 and 1135 which I placed on notice on 26th February 1969?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

quote.para: Question No. 1133 was answered on 13th May ('Hansard' page 1736) and Question No. 1135 was answered on 14th May ('Hansard' page 1819.)

talk.start.para: asked the Postmaster-General, upon notice:

item.para: Is it a fact that new subscribers are charged varying rates for their telephone services according to the distance of the subscriber from existing connection points?
Is he able to indicate the cost of the telephone cable per chain which is used for these new connections showing the varying costs per chain for the various distances from the main connection points?

Is he able to give a dissection of his cost in terms of profits made and labour costs for (a) mining and refining the copper and raw materials, (b) other manufacturing and (c) site preparation, erection and maintenance of cables?
What are the estimated costs of any government assistance to the industries involved in the cable manufacture?
Is he able to say how all or any of the costs referred to in question 3 compare with similar costs in other countries?

question.para: Mx Hulme - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: For economic reasons, there is a limit to the extent to which the Department can provide outdoor line plant at public expense for subscribers' telephone services. For this reason, a 'unit of construction' basis is adopted whereby each new applicant for service is given an allotment of 96 units which entitles him, irrespective of the actual cost, to 60 chains of new line plant or its equivalent. In practice, this means that, where no Departmental line plant exists from the exchange in the direction of an applicant's premises, and only one service is involved, the Department will erect new line plant for a maximum distance of 60 chains along the public road. If the applicant's premises are located beyond this point, then he is called upon to arrange for the provision of any further line plant necessary beyond the end of the departmentally provided plant. Therefore, the cost to the applicant of the private section of the line, whether constructed by the Department on his behalf, the applicant himself, or a contractor engaged by him, would depend on the distance from his premises to the point at which the departmental section of the line terminates.

question.para: The cost to applicants can also vary in accordance with the number of applicants concerned. For example, il there were two applicants located at the same distance from the exchange as the single applicant mentioned above, but along a different roadway, each of the two applicants would be allocated 96 units and the Department would provide construction to the extent of the combined allocation. Thus, the private section of the two applicants would be shorter and less costly than for the single applicant. Whilst this might appear to be anomalous to the latter, it will be appreciated that, so far as the Departmental sections of the lines are concerned, the same amount of money has been spent for each subscriber.

As 1 announced, in the House of Representatives on 28th November last, the Government has decided to assist country subscribers who are called upon to provide portion of their lines by providing funds for this purpose - on the basis that subscribers repay the amount involved. Under this scheme, interest is payable by the subscriber at the long term bond rate current at the time funds are approved for the work. Repayments of the principal may be made in instalments when the amount is over $100. Minimum instalments will be $100 a year in addition to interest of the balance outstanding and the maximum period over which repayments may be spread will be 10 years.

Importantly, subscribers wilt be relieved of the responsibility of carrying out maintenance on lines provided to Departmental specifications under the new conditions, subject to their bearing the cost of the main items of replacement material.

item.para: The type and consequently the cost of telephone cable for new connections, is dependent upon technical requirements for transmission limits for the area concerned. Generally, however, two pair plastic sheathed cable with a copper conductor weight of 4 lb per mile is used in metropolitan areas and cable with a conductor weight of 20 lb per mile is used in rural areas, again depending upon transmission requirements. The approximate costs of these types of cable, at ruling price, are $0.88, and $2.42 per chain, respectively. Costs ot installation are not included in these figures. 3. (a) No.

item.label: (b)
item.para: No.

item.label: (c)
item.para: Costs of construction and maintenance of plant, including site preparation are generally dependent on the types of plant provided in particular areas. The type of plant used may vary widely depending on a number of factors including geographical and geological conditions which may also determine a need for conduit. The costs do not include specific profit margins but are designed to recoup the true departmental outlay.
Financial assistance is nol given by my Department to industries involved in the manufacture of cable.

The information available to my Department indicates that the local manufacturers basic price for the type of cable under consideration, compares favourably with tender prices received from other countries.

talk.start.para: ns asked the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: Has he recently received requests to provide funds to assist research into multiple sclerosis?
If so, will he have inquiries made as to how and where this research could best be carried out?
If his inquiries show good chances of research being successful, will he provide sufficient funds for it to be undertaken either independently or in conjunction with some other project?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: Yes. I received a number of letters asking that Commonwealth funds be provided for research into multiple sclerosis. 2 and 3. Investigations are currently being undertaken to collect information on all medical research being carried out in Australia. This total information is not yet available but the following are the two major medical research projects related to multiple sclerosis which are supported by Commonwealth funds through the National Health and Medical Research Council.

item.label: (i)
item.para: Department of Microbiology, University ot Western Australia - Research into reovirus infection:

answer.para: This work is aimed at discovering how the body reacts to infection by 'slow' viruses (reoviruses), and particularly whether such infection causes chronic disease including multiple sclerosis and cancer. The head of the research unit. Professor Stanley, reports that 'as a result of Dr Alpers intensive work in this Held, the way has now been opened up for a new attack on diseases like multiple sclerosis, which almost certainly results from a virus infection of childhood, and other diseases of the central nervous system which have defied the attack made on them by medical science'.
Professor Stanley's group has been receiving a continuing Commonwealth grant for this work since 1963; the grant for 1969 was $32,398.

item.label: (ii)
item.para: Walter and Eliza Hall Institute:

answer.para: The Institute is similarly receiving a continuing grant from the National Health and Medical Research Council the amount of which for 1969 was $280,650. This grant is for cancer research and experimental immunology and an important part of this work is the study of autoimmune disease and the role of autoimmunity in the causation of a number of diseases, including multiple sclerosis.

With any research work the essential ingredients for success are a worthwhile, scientifically based project and a research worker with the interest, ability and facilities to carry out the work; and I have no doubt that the National Health and Medical Research Council which distributes the grants will continue to give sympathetic consideration to applications, which are so based, for research into multiple sclerosis.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Repatriation, upon notice:

quote.para: What would be the estimated cost of each proposal in the case for improved repatriation benefits presented by the Commonwealth Council of the Totally and Permanently Disabled Soldiers' Association of Australia to honourable members on 17th April?

talk.start.para: - The Minister for Repatriation has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

quote.para: Based on pensions in force at 31st March 1969, the estimated annual cost of each proposal would be:

subdebate.1.para: Notes: (1) The figure of $6,800,000 in Point1A above includes an estimated $189,000 arising from an increase in the Intermediate Rate pension which is adjusted automatically with increases in the Special Rate or General Rate pensions. It does not take account, however, of any consequential increase in sustenance allowance payable in prescribed circumstances at varying rates to members receiving medical treatment.

item.para: There is no means test on T. & P.I. pensions. The amount shown is the estimated cost of excluding T. & P.I. pension from consideration as income for the purposes of social services or service pension. The amount of $14,500,000 represents the estimated costs for living members and their dependants only; there would be significant additional costs if the concession were to be extended to dependants of deceased Special Rate pensioners.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Health, upon notice:

item.para: Did the then Prime Minister on 3rd January 1967 write to the Yarrowlumla Shire Council President stating that he had assured the New South Wales Minister for Local Government that the Canberra Abattoir would continue?

Was $320,000 spent in 1957 to provide chillers at the abattoir sufficient for a population of up to 250,000 and was a further expenditure of $270,000 anticipated to provide for a first class abattoir?
Did the Managing Director of Cootamundra Abattoirs approach senior officers of his Department in 1965 and suggest closing the Canberra Abattoir and offer to buy or lease its chilling facilities?

Did the Australian Capital Territory Advisory Council hold a public inquiry among sections of the industry and the public and find that sale or lease of the abattoir was not in the industry's or the public's interest and that freshly killed meat kept better than imported refrigerated meat?
Has the abattoir successfully tendered in competition with alternative suppliers for the supply of 1,000,000lb of meat yearly to public institutions?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

At the present time this ranges from 2 years sea time11/2 years shore time in the best case to 34 yearssea 1 year shore in the worst.

The Naval Board is very conscious of the unsatisfactory situation existing in this important branch of the RAN. However, it is of paramount importance that ships are manned at the required level of skill and experience.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Services, upon notice:

item.para: Did Australia support the adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in the General Assembly of the United Nations?
What is the text of article 25 (1) of that Declaration?

Has his attention been drawn to a recent survey in the City of Melbourne by the Institute of Applied Economics establishing the existence of relative poverty in that city affecting an estimated 7% of the population?

As the existence of this poverty contravenes the undertaking in article 25 (1) of the Declaration, will he immediately arrange for a wide ranging campaign to be undertaken to eliminate relative poverty in Australia?

If so, will be outline details of this comprehensive programme, including details of the time phases for each stage of the programme, the objectives to be reached during each phase, the method of measuring success of each stage, and the type of administrative apparatus, as well as practical policies, which will be involved in the campaign?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: Yes.

'Everyone has the right to a standard of living adequate for the health and well-being of himself and of his family, including food, clothing, housing and medical care and necessary social services, and the right to security in the event of unemployment, sickness, disability, widowhood, old age or other lack of livelihood in circumstances beyond his control'.

In June 1966, the Institute of Applied Economic Research, University of Melbourne, conducted a survey into living conditions in Melbourne. The survey did not set out to measure the number of persons living in absolute poverty but rather proceeded by tentatively adopting an arbitrary level of income which was assumed to represent the poverty benchmark - if income did not exceed this level, the income unit was likely to be in poverty. The poverty benchmark adopted was based on an income equivalent to the basic wage plus child endowment for a family consisting of a man, dependent wife and two children, plus a small arbitrary loading.

answer.para: On this basis the first stage of the study concluded that when adult income units were examined, one person in eighteen appeared to be in poverty - when income units headed by a juvenile were included the figure was one in fifteen. Final results of the second stage of the study have yet to be published. However, in a paper presented at the Australian Institute of Political Science Summer School held in January this year, Professor Henderson stated that a subsequent study in depth of persons, mainly rather poor ones, who were classed as living in poverty in the first stage revealed income not previously disclosed and assets not included in the first survey. The effect of this finding he said reduced the proportion of the total population in need to between 4% and 5%. 4 and 5. Any standard adopted for measuring poverty involves arbitrary judgments and opinions will differ as to what constitutes poverty. It is the Government's desire to remove, as far as possible, any poverty that may exist in the community. Indeed, the progress the Government has made, and is making, in this area compares more than favourably with that of most other countries who supported die adoption of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights in the General Assembly of the United Nations.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Social Services, upon notice:

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: The Commonwealth Conciliation and Arbitration Commission announced in its decision of 8th July 1966 concerning the Metal Trade Award that it intended to insert in the award an interim provision prescribing that no adult male employee should be paid a weekly wage for working the standard hours of work of less than his appropriate basic wage plus $3.75 a week. It was intended that the increase be implemented expeditiously in other awards, where appropriate, upon union application.

answer.para: In the National Wage Case of 1967 the total wage was introduced. The Commission announced that the total wage would be arrived at by adding $1 a week to the weekly award wages of all adult males and females.

Thus the minimum total wage was calculated by adding the announced increase to the minimum award wage prescribed in the Commission's decision of July 1966. (A subsequent increase was also added in October 1968).

The minimum total wage so arrived at is, under Commonwealth awards, different in every State. State awards in three States also include provisions prescribing rates of minimum wage for adult males similar in concept to the Commonwealth award provision. These too are prescribed at different levels.

The lowest prescribed minimum total wage for an adult male is under the Commonwealth award in Brisbane ($37.10 per week) and the highest is under the State Award in Tasmania ($40.45 per week). Thirty per cent of these amounts would represent $11.13 and $12.14 respectively, these figures being less than the current rate of pensions.

subdebateinfo.title: Territorial Waters: Commonwealth and State Rights (Question No. 1502)

talk.start.para: asked the Attorney-General, upon notice.

item.para: Has his attention been drawn to the paper delivered at the University of Sydney on 3rd May under the auspices of the Australian Conservation Foundation by Sir Percy Spender, formerly President of the International Court of Justice, and particularly to his conclusions that (a) excluding what are commonly known as inland waters, the territorial boundaries of Queensland and other States end at low water mark, (b) the territorial seas bordering Australia, and the sea bed thereof with all its natural resources, are those of the Commonwealth, not those of any State, and (c) dominion over the sea bed and the natural resources of the whole of the Continental Shelf, commencing at low water mark, and the right to explore and exploit these, or permit others to do so, is vested exclusively in the Commonwealth?

If so, in view of the implications of Sir Percy's opinion for Commonwealth and Stale legislation on submerged lands (petroleum) and the continental shelf (living and non-living natural resources), has consideration been given to his suggestion that the Commonwealth institute proceedings against, for example, Queensland before the High Court to have these issues determined?

Is Sir Percy one of the authorities distinguished in the field of international law from whom the Government has sought advice on Australia's rights to claim the waters inside the Great Barrier Reef or in other areas as internal waters?
If so, has be been asked to advise whether and to what extent Australia can claim the waters of the Gulf of Carpentaria as internal waters?

talk.start.para: - The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

item.para: 1 was present when Sir Percy Spender delivered his paper.

The Commonwealth has no plans for instituting proceedings in the High Court. The Commonwealth Parliament has not yet legislated with regard to off-shore minerals other than petroleum. With regard to petroleum, it should be noted that pursuant to an Agreement dated 16th October 1967, the Commonwealth and the States, including Queensland, agreed to put the constitutional questions aside and to adopt a scheme of joint Commonwealth-State legislation (see the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967-1968 and the corresponding State Acts). The Commonwealth has legislated with regard to the living natural resources of the continental shelf- see the Continental Shelf (Living Natural Resources) Act 1968, which, when proclaimed, will replace the Pearl Fisheries Act 1952-1953. State fisheries legislation applies inside the 3-mile limit and has so applied since Federation.
and 4. Advice was not sought from Sir Percy Spender on either of these matters. His comments regarding the powers of the States have been noted with interest.
